title: Posing Beauty in African American Culture

summary: Features 200 images from 1,200+ glass plate negatives by photographer Grant Castner (1863-1941).

title: Bark! Indigenous Cultural Expression
summary: Explores use of bark by Indigenous communities globally, highlighting objects from Museum's Ethnographic collection.

title: Seventeen Men: Portraits of the Men of the 25th US Colored Troops
summary: This traveling exhibition features a series of portraits by professional artist, illustrator, and historian Shayne Davidson, based on an exceedingly rare tintype photograph album featuring seventeen of the men who served in the 25th Infantry, United States Colored Troops (USCT), Company G during the Civil War.

title: On the Edge of War: A Monmouth Before the Revolution
summary: This exhibition provides a personal look at the lives and conditions of Monmouth's men, women, and children in the decades leading up to the Revolutionary War. The downstairs gallery will immerse you in the solitude and sounds familiar to Colonial Monmouth, where you can hear the stories of what life was life - told by some of the residents themselves! Also, the Hartshorne Gallery contains fascinating documents to illustrate growing frustrations of Monmouth's residents,  painting, Washington Rallying the Troops at Monmouth

title: Choices: A The Covenhoven Family and the Battle of Monmouth
summary: Visit the historic 1752 home of William and Elizabeth Covenhoven, which was used as a makeshift headquarters by British General Sir Henry Clinton and his officers in the days before the Battle of Monmouth. Discover the choices that were available to the Revolutionary-era residents of Freehold as the British came through on their way to Sandy Hook.

title: Beneath the Floorboards: A Whispers of the Enslaved at Marlpit Hall
summary: A two-time award-winning exhibit now at Marlpit Hall, a c. 1762 farmhouse once owned by the Taylor family of Middletown. The exhibit interprets the home from the perspective of seven of the twelve known enslaved men, women and children who once lived and worked there, exploring the often-overlooked topic of slavery in the North.

title: Ecosystems at Risk: Threatened and Endangered in New Jersey
summary: Presents major ecosystems in New Jersey and highlights threatened and endangered species in each, from bobcats in the Skylands to Piping Plovers along the Atlantic Coast.

title: The Civil War Flag Collection of New Jersey
summary: Rare collection of flags carried into battle by New Jersey's Civil War soldiers. Main Building - South Gallery, 1st floor. Flags change periodically.

title: Written in the Rocks: Fossil Tales of New Jersey
summary: Features New Jersey's Dryptosaurus, the world's first known carnivorous dinosaur, and life-sized cast of Hadrosaurus foulkii.

title: American Perspectives: The Fine Art Collection
summary: Highlights diversity of voices in 19th-21st century American art, including significant NJ artists.

title: Pretty Big Things: Stories of New Jersey History
summary: Long-term core exhibition featuring large artifacts from Cultural History collection documenting everyday life from colonial times through present.

title: A Much Moved People: Preserving Traditions of the Delaware Indians
summary: Story of Delaware Indian migrations from 1740s to 1890s, featuring objects from late 1700s to early 1900s.

title: Cultures in Competition: Indians & Europeans in Colonial New Jersey
summary: Seventeenth-century Dutch, Swedish and English competition to start colonies and develop fur trade with Indians.

title: New Jersey's Original People: Interpreting the Archaeological Collection
summary: Story of New Jersey's native Lenni Lenape people from 13,000 years ago to 17th century through archaeological collections.

title: Robert Duran
summary: Features paintings, drawings, and watercolors by Robert Duran (1938-2005) from 1967 to late 1990s. Born in Salinas, California, to a Filipino father and Shawnee mother, Robert Duran (1938–2005) arrived in New York in the early 1960s via San Francisco, where he soon became part of the artistic milieu associated with Bykert Gallery. Originally a sculptor, Duran and his approach to painting offer an alternative to both the hard-edge geometric abstraction and minimalism that dominated much of the ‘60s and ‘70s in New York. Duran’s acrylic wash surfaces and “color shapes,” as critic Carter Ratcliff called them, at times resemble petroglyphs, and at others take on cartographic or even geological qualities. Despite a critically successful career in the New York art world, around 1980 Duran moved with his family to Hillsdale, New Jersey, where he privately continued to develop his painting style.

title: History Beneath Our Feet: Archaeology of a Capital City
summary: Long history of human activity in Trenton through archaeology, featuring excavations at ten locations from prehistoric times to present.

title: Beyond the Tangible: Non-objective Abstraction from the Collection
summary: 26 non-objective abstract works by 22 artists from the Fine Art collection, created since late 1930s.

title: New Jersey Arts Annual: Reemergence
summary: Highlights work of visual artists and craftspeople from around NJ. 127 works by 95 artists selected for inclusion. Theme: Reemergence.

title: Jaw Dropping World of Sharks
summary: Explores sharks' 400-million-year history, biology, fossil record, conservation and cultural significance using Museum collection specimens.

title: Science History Art: Experience Your State Museum
summary: Glimpse into diversity of Museum collections in Natural History, Archaeology & Ethnography, Cultural History and Fine Art - over 2,000,000 specimens, artifacts and objects.
